values: The poem called Blueberry Girl is one of the best blessings for a baby girl I've ever heard.  Give yourself a 2 minute audio treat and go listen!

Oh, LJ, you poor neglected thing.  I've been living on Facebook and Twitter of late, and when I'm not on those, I'm on Tar Valon.  Networking is all well and good, but so much of it feels empty or frivilous, and I need to revel in that from time to time.

Not much news: house hunting again today, grateful for my job (mostly becuase I haven't been in this week), and reveling in my nerdities.  I'm also going to start the "Couch to 5K" program - we'll see how long I stick with it.
I am clearing out my magical truck - books are being donated to Greenhaven and articles are being divied up for friends and family.  I'm not walking away, but my path is leading me elsewhere, and I don't need as many props on this path.  I'm not even sure I can take them along, to be honest.  But changes aren't always bad.

So, , there are books and tools coming your way!

I wish I had decent news.  Life is being...interesting...again.  So instead, I ignored all of that today and did about diddle squat.  But I did make another round of Oreo truffles (still not perfected) and did some laundry.

I need to work on my writing some more, but the time it takes coupled with the sheer amount of time I spend in front of a computer at work make me very sad and unwilling to do what I need to.  I actually find myself avoiding my compute of late, if only because of how much time I spend shackled to the damn thing all week at work.
Which reminds me, I hate being known as capable and dependable.  It ends with me doing a lot more work.


But despite all that, I'm fairly content.  Jake (cousin-in-law) and Mark are trading cards in the other room, I just finished a cinnamon roll, and I get to spend tomorrow with my mommy-person.  And The Dragon Reborn is actually moving at a good pace, so my book reading is going pretty well.  Can't complain too loudly, really.

Reprinted in its entirety from the e-mail:

Dear Tom --

On Tuesday at 8 a.m., I will stand trial for speaking three truthful words: "I am gay."

On Tuesday, I will face a panel of colonels who will decide whether or not to fire me -- to discharge me for "moral and professional dereliction" under the military's "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policy.

On Tuesday, I will try to prove that it's not immoral to tell the truth.

As an infantry officer, an Iraq combat veteran and a West Point graduate with a degree in Arabic, I refuse to lie to my commanders. I refuse to lie to my peers. I refuse to lie to my subordinates.

My case requires that I provide personal testimony from people who can attest to my character. That's why several members of my military unit have written letters of support and offered to testify on my behalf.

Now I need your help. ANYONE who believes the Army should not fire me can take a stand right now. I am bringing a statement of support to Tuesday's trial and I need you to add your signature to it. Will you support me by signing this statement before Tuesday?

http://www.couragecampaign.org/SupportDan

I want to thank the 141,262 people who have signed the "Don't Fire Dan" letter launched a few weeks ago by the Courage Campaign and CREDO Mobile to President Obama, asking him to take leadership to bring this tragic policy to an end.

The momentum is building. This week, 77 members of Congress signed a letter to the President citing my service as an example of why DADT should be repealed. And a Gallup poll was recently released showing that 69 percent of Americans -- including 58 percent of Republicans - favor allowing openly gay men and lesbian women to serve their country .

As I learned at West Point, deception and lies poison a unit and cripple a fighting force. That's why more than 70 of my fellow West Point graduates have also come out of the closet to join Knights Out, the organization I co-founded to build support for the repeal of "Don't Ask, Don't Tell".

The only way we will eventually overturn "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" is by speaking up together. You can help me fight back right now by adding your name to my statement of support. On Tuesday morning, I will bring your signature -- and thousands of others -- to my trial as a demonstration of your collective support:

http://www.couragecampaign.org/SupportDan

National security means many things, but the thing that makes us secure in our nation and homes is love. What makes me a better soldier, leader, Christian and human being is love. And I'm not going to hide my love.

Love is worth it.

Thank you for your support.

Daniel W. Choi
1LT, IN
New York Army National Guard

Courage Campaign Issues is part of the Courage Campaign's online organizing network that empowers more than 700,000 grassroots and netroots supporters to push for progressive change and full equality in California.

Last night we went to the Turkey Festival.  Good food, but more importantly, the library has a booth where they sell off books - you make a donation for whatever you take.  I had donated quite a large chunk of books and DVDs to the library (I found a good 7 or 8 of my donated items when browsing), and they had really good selection this year.  So, I came home with 10 books for 10 bucks.  Added to some collections, got some Shakespeare, picked up Lake Wobegon Days (I really enjoy Garrison Keillor) and a I fairly bounced home.  I need to go back tonight and get more.

I have to agree with  - I feel lucky to live in a time where books are allowed, readily available, and affordable.  I don't "need" most of the books I have, but I love them, and I can let friends and family love them too.  I'm just going to hate moving them when we find a house...

Who cares?  I HAVE BOOKS!  ::runs off squee-ing::

So, I did some more writing.  But I need a little critical feedback; actually, I just need any feedback!  Please be brutal - I want this story arc to be something people might be interested in, and I need people to pick at it.  Mark already found some glaring flaws that have been repaired, but he hasn't read it at all.


Outside of writing, I got an old rocking chair from my Grandma Jean today, and the Turkey Festival is this weekend.  Yummy, yummy turkey...and we're going to fill the freezer with it!

From  

“The problem with Livejournal is that we all think we are so close, but really, we know nothing about each other. Hence, I want you to ask me something you think you should know about me. Something that should be obvious, but you have no idea about. Then post this in your LJ and find out what people don’t know about you.”

So, let's try the experiment, shall we?

Well, I had a nasty headache yesterday, which sucked.  Today is a mish-mash kind of day - I made a chicken and rice dish for lunch, vacuumed, and am getting ready to clean my oven.  I also need to go water plants at work, check my garden, and do another round of dishes, plus laundry.  But this is the first weekend I've had in 3 years that I haven't had to go clean my mom's office - I lost that job last week.  There is much drama around that situation, and my poor mom is kinda stuck in the middle of it (I am not a cause of the issue).  

In gardening news, I have green hands, but I kill my herbs every time.  I pot them in regular potting soil (they seem to dislike anything with food), I try to water only when they need it, but I still kill them.  Any ideas?

So, I've been slowly going veg over the last month or so, and I am really happy with it.  Most days, I strive for at least one meatless meal, and I'm finding some great choices!  For example, I just had Amy's Indian Mattar Paneer ( a frozen meal I picked up at Wal-Mart for about $3) and it was AMAZING!  It was a little tray of happiness, and just enough to keep me going.  And, between cutting back on meat, cutting milk out of my diet, and moving in to our new building, my headaches are nearly gone!  I have one today, but it's low grade, and I'm okay with that.

...and that's the only real news in my life right now.  Wow, that's a tiny bit sad.

has a new house!  I helped her move yesterday - I'm paying for it today, that's for sure.  It probably wouldn't have been an issue except we moved our office this week too.  Actually, it's not an issue.  I'm just terribly out of shape.

Looking forward to not much - today is my last day of my cleaning job (it was not an amiable parting either), and I need to take Mark to JC Penny's to find khaki's and such for his buddy's wedding later this month.  At least I have a dress for that occasion!  The weather is gorgeous, and I need to go water the new plants at my office, as well as part of my garden.  If I could only figure out what I"m doing wrong with my herbs...
No real news, just kinda cruising mentally.  Moved our office today - sweaty, nasty work, but I"m glad that we're done.  I think I'm ready to crash out and do nothing, I think!

Hey everybody. Long, exhausting weekend. I find that I'm having issues shielding at these kinds of events. I can handle my grief, it's keeping the grief of others from pulling me apart that's hard.

Did see a super cool statue-thingie by the side of the road - a winged moose! It was in Gray Summit, MO. Alas, we were unable to get a picture of it. I can't help but wonder if  has a picture of it yet, since it's pretty close to him.

Trying something new for dinner: Turkey and quinoa, and a frozen pie treat.  The pie is just a container of yogurt mixed with a container of whipped topping, then frozen.  A gal I used to work with raved about it, so I thought we'd give it a shot.

We have no plans since Mark is working, but I imagine other people might.  Either way, have a safe and fun weekend.

What kind of poison is your personality?

Ergotoxine

You're so deadly you've chipped out a space in history! You were responsible for famines and tens of thousands of people fell victim to your deadly touch. Despite being a lowly grain fungus, you've managed to afflict people with fantastic flares of gout, hallucinations, ecstatic mania, and of course death. Hell they even blamed the Salem witch trials on you.

Click Here to Take This Quiz


Quizzes and Personality Tests

My grandmother passed last Friday.

I am in a funk, and her passing is only part of it.  I feel worthless most days - the changes in my eating habits have alleviated part of the headache issue (lactose of all the bloody things), but my weight issues are still just that - an issue.  Things at work feel tense (mostly due to the economy), and things have been tense here at home as well.

My brother-in-law graduated Sunday - his is the second graduating class for Bio Engineering at the U of I.  The boy is so smart it's scary.  You should see Stephanie - I want one, even if it is creepy looking.  But watching him graduate is a bit of a knife-twist for me: I should have been done with school.  I'd like to go back, but I'm not sure I can afford it.  I just want my damn degree, even if it means nothing, which is an added strain to the week.


Oh well, it is what it is.  At least my desk has this: .

I've been on a bit of an emotional roller coaster of late.  I fight against it, but I think I need to get some of it out.

My Grandma Jennie is dying of cancer.  They found it in January, after she broke the same bone in her arm two times over Christmas.  They went through a huge battery of tests, and it is kidney cancer.  Since that time, she has made her peace, has seen her only sister, all her children, all three of us grandkids, and her only great-grandchild.  She is ready, but still she lingers.
I talked to my mom last night for a while, and we got on the subject (naturally).  She mentioned how Grandma wanted to be the crazy old lady in the dusty black dress, the with the giant herb garden.  She won't be able to do that now, and it breaks my heart.  She was one of those fiercely independent women who took care of themselves, who didn't run to the doctor over every little thing, and this is her reward.  Somehow, it seems wrong.
She taught me so much: to be strong, to hold on to your beliefs, to travel anywhere and to not be afraid to ask for directions.  She's always been a hard woman to love, but I always did.  And I always will.



Outside of that, things are moving okay.  Not a lot of luck on the house front, but that's okay.  My plants are growing out of control (thanks, green hands!), and I need to get them in the ground out at my dad's.  We're both still employed; his job is going great, mine's doing well, but I worry.  With school budgets continuing to get cut, people are ordering less; the less work there is, it makes me wonder how long until hours start getting culled a bit.  Can't say I would blame them one little bit, but that doesn't mean I can't worry.
Anyone have suggestions for dealing with an almost constant headache I've had since like mid-April?

I was sent a link by one of my co-workers to an amazing essay on Twilight.  It may irritate some of you fans out there, but it is an amazing piece nonetheless. 

Nothing much in real news, just more headaches and irrational worries about work.  Hope everyone's doing well and staying dry.

I am a terrible updater.
We've been looking for a house.  My grandma is dying of cancer.  My brother STILL has not left for the service.  Neither of us is sick, finally.  My big brother is getting married.  My best friend is going to be a mommy.  I have reconnected with the coven that gave me purpose.  

And on Friday, I got called a lesbian, along with 2 of my female friends at the card shop.  The guy who said it is a total idiot, and this has now been added to our running list of "WTF Dude?" comments that come out of his mouth.

Anything shaking with you guys?

I was poking around the big ol' internet this morning and found something that may interest a few of you.  English Russia had a post about "bear growers" up, which had some good pictures.  They have several fascinating posts about Russia and Russian life.  Enjoy!

Just for you readers out there: www.goodreads.com

It tracks your books, lets you write reviews, offers suggestions, has fun and challenging trivia...I love it!

So, we are down a car.  Mark had a wreck last week due to the weather - he's fine, but PantsCar bit the dust.  It's a bit irritating, to say the least.  I'm less than enamored with my job at the moment - glad I have it, just not enjoying it so much.  I think that's because I'm on the late shift this month.

But I have a reason to cheer - We Have a New President!  Yay change!

Nothing really to report.

Lots of family issues going on, lots of emotional upheaval and whatnot.  It happens.

Really wish there was more going on; work is crazy, I built myself an Esper deck, and that's about it!

So, I have my 2009 reading list.  Yay!  16 books so far, and that should ideally hold me until about April, maybe a bit longer.  It will depend on how social I get, how involved I get in my video games, and other such variables.  Want to see the list?

And yes, 4 of these are compilations of short stories.  Sadly, 2 0r 3 other books I wanted to add to the stack are missing!  I can't find either of my copies of Jane Eyre or my copy of Pride and Prejudice.  There was another book I thought of last night on the cusp of sleep and I cannot remember what it was.  Oh well.  Book list!
Mort - Sir Terry Prattchett
Pyramids - Sir Terry Prattchett
Interesting Times - Sir Terry
Eye of the World - Robert Jordan (Yes, I allowed myself to get sucked in.)
Son of a Witch - Gregory Maguire
I Am Legend
The Eyre Affair - Jasper Fforde
An Assembly Such as This (Book 1 of the Adventures of Fitzwilliam Darcy, Gentleman series) - Pamela Aidan
Jonathan Strange & Mr Norrell - Susanna Clarke
2 tomes of Batman stories
After the King: Stories in honor of JRR Tolkien's Lord of the Rings
A Confederacy of Dunces
Life Mask - Emma Donoghue
Saving General Washington
Mammoth Book of Vampires - Collected short stories on a vampire theme

Am I missing something?  Any of these that you liked or hated?  What do you recommend?

Sorry if this post ends up being a bit soap boxy, but I want to get this out of my head and see if other people agree or if they think I'm crazy. 
Life has been good to me - no major health issues, great job, loving supportive husband - and I do what I can to give back.  I donate to wildlife causes, I regularly sign petitions over at Care2 and give FreeRice but I always feel like I could do more.  So I've gone through my books and try to pull books to donate to the library or that I give away of Freecycle, I take clothing in to Goodwill and post it on Freecycle, and we've started a recycling can at home.  I also pull all the recyclable bottles and cans at my mom's office when I clean.  But I still feel like I could do more.
So, for 2009, I'm going to try something new.  I'm going to reduce the trips that get made to Wal-Mart, going to try to buy locally, but I've got a few other radical ideas I want to try.  I'm going to build nesting areas for mason orchard bees at both of my folk's houses.  I'm going to take over part of my dad's garden and grow green beans that I can can for the coming winter and next year.  I'm going to trade off with my dad's neighbor to get more of his apples again this fall (they weren't pretty but they have amazing flavor and are great for baking!); I'm also going to see if Chad & MIndy have eggs they'd be willing to sell.
I want to live a little healthier, and take care of my community.  I want to make small changes that can have a larger impact.  Am I being too idealistic, or am I starting to get myself on a better path?  Any suggestions of how I can make this work or what else I can do?

Mom and I made these last week and they're pretty good!

1 cup butter,soft                    3/4 cup coarsely crushed potato chip
1/2 cup sugar                        3/4 cup coarsely crushed pretzels
1 egg yolk                             1 cup semisweet choc chips
1 teaspoon vanilla extract       1 cup white baking chips
1 3/4 cups flour
 
1. preheat oven to 350
 
2. combind butter & sugar until fluffy, add yolk & vanilla. slowly add flour,mix well.
    Stir in potato chips & pretzels.
 
3. Form tablespoon size into 3 inch logs. place on ungreased, bake 14 to 18 mins. Cool
    completely.
 
4. Melt choc & white chips in seperate bowls, dip each end, chill @ 10 min.

I'M BACK ONLINE!!!  I bought myself a laptop this week, so now (hopefully) I will be a somewhat regular web-presence.  

Life's been hectic.  The weather is, of course, just lovely.  The ice around here brought down several trees and power lines; we lost power for about an hour and a half at work this morning.  My dad had part of a tree snap under the weight of the ice, and it fell right on four of the wire reindeer that my stepmom wanted out in the yard.  Dad HATES those reindeer, so he was practically giggling when he told me about that.

Not really much to discuss.  The holidays are rapidly approaching, and we are no where near ready.  I went to get gifts for my dad and my in-laws tonight, but I was not successful.  The restaurant I wanted to get them gift certificates to was inaccessible as a building 2 doors down was on fire.  I'm hoping no one was hurt, especially not the firefighters or rescue workers.  Those people don't get enough respect for the job they do.

Anybody got big holiday plans?  A really good cookie recipe?  Any news at all?  Please talk to me; I miss you guys!

Nothing of any importance.  Making pork roast marinated in apple cider for dinner with fresh sour dough or French baguette.  See what my life has sunk to?  I'm excited about this...and my new Dyson vacuum.

Oh yes, and the Chibithulu! It's from Munchin Cthulhu, which is a lot of fun!  Sickeningly cute, isn't he?  Its a little ray of sunshine in a bad week.

We made it!  We are officially married!
Everything was beautiful, and everyone had a really good time.  There will be pictures up once we get them developed.  Thanks to everyone for making it a great day!!!

I hope you like the music - I'm rather a fan of David Byrne and I'm getting to like Brian Eno quite a bit as well.
So! It's been quite some time...life is a bit crazy. Not sure if I'd posted it before, but I'm now working at The Library Store, Inc.  It's a library supply company, and I'm in the drop ship department.  My specialty is furniture, mainly book trucks and shelving.  It's a definite change from banking, but I really like it.  It's a great company with really good people.
I also have some friends again.  Sad statement, but true.  It's nice to have friends locally, and they are both female, which is even nicer!  We have a lot in common and sometimes the similarities are scary!  But it's a nice change.  The guys at Gamers Sanctuary are nice, but it's nice to be with other females.
Wedding stuff is trucking right along.  I'm making peace with it - marrying Mark has never been an issue; it's all the details.  And those aren't all that bad.  Oh yeah, if you haven't RSVP'd I do need those ASAP - the invite list is about 375 people and if you can't make it, that may make room for someone else who wants to come.  (And if you can't come, I won't be all upset - life happens way too fast sometimes!)

On another positive note, my brother is sober, and is joining the Navy.  I think this may be the best thing for him.  3 meals a day, medical and dental, and some much needed discipline.  I guess on the test they give, a 35 is passing, 50 and up is good....Tim got a 74.  99.9% of jobs in the Navy are open to him, and he wants to go into...(drum roll)...nuclear engineering and submarines.  I know!!  WTF did that come from?  Nobody knows....

Anyways, I need to scoot.  Hope everyone is well and not completely soaked or wind damaged!

Thank you to everyone for your thoughts and well wishes.

And now, the saga of Tim continues.  It would seem that Dippy Doo was indeed drunk (.177 BAC), was at least in a helmet, but was wearing shorts and flipflops.  His wallet literally saved his ass; without it, he'd probably be sittin' lopsided.  His excuse for the accident?  He blames his girl-friend-person-whatever for texting him and he was trying to answer it!  I doubt it's the truth, but who can say?
Oh yes, and the reason he had the BMW?  He completely wore 3 tires down to the cords in the last 3 months (mostly from burn-outs and other idiot manuevers); his bike was jacked up and lacked a rear tire; and he HAD to be at work.  So, Dad loaned him the Beemer.  The catch?  Tim hasn't had a job for a MONTH.  He lied, outright.  If he'd told the truth, he would have been allowed to sleep at Dad's or they'd have gotten him a ride home.  But he lied instead.

Part of me wishes that I could upload pictures of the bike (which are on my phone).  I'd show you before and after, but it just...yikes.   It cost my dad $750 to get back the ruins of his now useless and ruined bike.  And that was just to cover towing and $500 on the DUI charge Tim now has.

And Tim shows no real remorse, no real regret.  He said some very nasty things last night, and said more today, and then has the nerve to be irked at the apparent lack of sympathy from his parents.
As of this post, he has also been removed from the wedding party.



As a happier note, I need current addresses from everyone - we start invitation addressing next week!

My mom called me about 40 minutes ago - my brother apparently wrecked a motorcycle tonight.  She said she'd just gotten called and was told "he's awake and talking and we're going to admit him overnight."  I guess he's more or less alright - sratched and bruised to hell, I'm sure.  He was on O' Lucky, the BMW, so at least he wasn't hot roddin' on his bike.  But, lately, he hasn't been wearing his gear, and...if you've ever met Tim or heard me talk about him, you know how he is.  Mr Full Volume in EVERYTHING.  Dad said Tim had one of his (dad's) jackets and a helmet,  but that doesn't mean he was wearing them. 

I do love him, but godsdammit, boy, the worry you put your family through.  I just hope he was sober, for Dad's insurance, if nothing else.


...and now, I can't sleep.

And the greenest icon I have to celebrate it!

Not much news - hunting the elusive job and, despite a few promising sightings, still have not captured one.  Have a new trail to follow tonight.
Mark got me beautiful flowers this afternoon and decorated my window sill in the kitchen.  He wasn't here to give them to me, but it was so very sweet of him...

Really, nothing new, despite my trying, although there IS new stuff in the apartment.  Table WITH CHAIRS (!), freezer, dresser...good stuff, man.  Me gramma moved this weekend and we got some stuff that we needed.


So how's you guys?

Um, how did I go 5 weeks without a post?  Not that I really have any news.  Just wedding anxiety and a bout with a migraine that landed me in the ER on St Pat's.  No new job (though not from a lack of trying), no luck at my current job (everyone is pissed all the time), and on and on.
A big plus, we have a new card shop in Pekin.  They're really nice and affordable, so I've been going to Friday Night Magic and am in the process of building a few new decks.  It's funny - I still think of myself as a noob, but the noobs are asking me what to do with their decks!  I guess Mark's ramblings are getting through to some part of my brain...

Basically, my wishes on this wedding have been ignored.  The wedding itself is the cause of my anxiety (and bad dreams which leads to lack of sleep...), and I have no real fears about actually being (or getting) married, under the right circumstances.   However, my dad has spent  an awful lot of money on the wedding, so I don't want to up and elope  and basically waste all of their money, time, and effort, not to mention hurt feelings.
So, here;s my question - Is it wrong to get married before your wedding and not tell your family?

I know that quite a few people have posted it, but Gary Gygax died this morning.
Damn.  It kinda hurts; he changed so much, and gave us nerds an outlet.  And this sums up why pretty well.


We're going to miss you.  Let's hope you get a really good game going by the time we catch up.

What happens to the time?  I feel sometimes like all I do is go to work and sleep and look for a new job.  Which covers about 90% of my day, really.  I miss posting and catching up on the news from everybody, but since I'm on a computer all day at work and Mark's got the internet on his machine, I miss out on it usually.  Mostly, I get sick of staring at a computer all day.  

I don't have any news really.  Just the repeating message that I don't really want to go through with this wedding.  Don't get me wrong, I want to marry Mark.  I just don't want the wedding.  I don't care about the flowers or the dresses or the jewelry (excepting my hatred of pearls) or the food or anything else.  I just want a small quiet affair and to be married.  I don't want the wedding is all.  

And then, I feel guilty.  

From the way everyone acts you're supposed to want to be involved, you're supposed to be excited and anxious, you're supposed to *care* about it.  And I don't.

Okay, so its been a while.  I just wanted to note that we're having a snowy thunderstorm today!  It is so cool...
And I made quiche and it is delicious.

No real news.  Mark's computer is on the fritz so we're using mine.  Oh joy; I'm starting to refer to the machine as "Sir Lags-a-lot" (which I ripped off of an AMV maker of the same title).  But Internet is internet so I won't bitch too much.

We survived the ice; hope you all did as well.  I've got errands to run and so my mind is not in posting mode.  gotta run!

Wow, I didn't think that I would get that kind of response!  And I'm not entirely sure who wanted pictures and who wanted invites, but I think I know who wants what!

Julie, were you wanting pics as well?

mmm, I gots me a mouthful of leftovers!  Sweet potatoes are the side dish of the gods...

Very little to report, actually.  We got a new king size bed and life is awesome.  Wedding plans are rolling smoothly, and I do have pics of my dress coming soon to certain people who ask nicely.  But not for Mark (sorry babe), or to anyone who thinks they're going to send them to him either.  I only get one shot at complete surprise and my dress is it!  
Oh yeah, that jogged my memory:  If you want an invite, zip me a line!  I'm pretty sure I know who all on the list can make it and would be interested, but sometimes I'm not too sure either.  

Yep, got no real news.  I think I'll go finish my turkey and then finish painting the living room.  Ta!

Woah, its been a week?  I'm slipping in my old age.  Or something.  I think I'll go with something.
There really isn't much news to report.  Work is ... interesting?  There's a major shake up going on and, once again, as the promotions and advancements happen, I get left in the corner.  Why?  It's not that I'm not good enough; its because I do my job very well, and that we don't have another teller to fill that spot.  "Eventually" I get to move up front and do full-time marketing and receptionist duties.  "Eventually."  Unless one of the gals at our other branch comes back, and if the other manager is still thinking about leaving.  Then I might get the branch manager position.  But that's almost in Bloomington.  Which ain't cool.

Wedding stuff is proceeding smoothly - I'm okay with Karen doing it all.  I don't have to sweat most of it!  Mom seems to be happy as long as I'm happy; I really don't want it becoming a sore spot...

I don't really have anything new to talk about, but it's been a while since I posted, so I feel vaugely guilty.  I don't get it either.

I DID buy a new car on the 18th.  A 2007 Kia Rio, silver.  No name yet, but she'll get one!  Outside of that, I did find some good tux options and a very nice bridesmaid dress and invitations yesterday.  I'm worried my 'rents are spending too much on this shindig but everytime I protest, they keep saying "We only get to do this once!"  I'm trying to keep that in perspective, but its hard sometimes.

Well, wedding stuff is proceeding nicely.  We have the venue, the reception hall, the photographer, the DJ, the dress...and today Karen and I started getting the reception hall dec stuff.
I promised Mark I would'nt talk about wedding stuff for a month, but I can write it!
I'm a wee bitty bit excited.  And now, I must do laundry!

Mark and I set the date for the wedding: October 11, 2008. As of now, I have no details. My Dad and Stepmonster are pushing and pushing for places they like, regardless of what we really want. I have shopped for a dress, and even tried two on. (I felt like a cow wrapped in silk and lace.) I just have a hard time justifying that kind of money for something I will wear ONE TIME, and then put in storage. I know, I konw, its your wedding gown, you only do this once, etc., but what we want is being overridden before we can even say what it is we want. I am grateful that my mom and Mark's parents agree that it is OUR wedding and that we should do it our way. Now if I could get the other two to listen... Enough wedding rant! There will be plenty of time for that later. How's everyone else's life running? Crazy? Smooth? Who has big announcements or randomness to soothe my brain?

Well, at least they didn't harp on the wedding tonight.  And I told them we weren't talking about it.  That slowed them down.  Instead my dad thought it fit to remind me my car is dying and that I need a new one.  Then he started talking about houses, and good little towns to live in.  Like Emden.  Always with that little spiel...
And then we have to start on the kids thing again.  Sweet angry Jesus I'm already sick of the "kids are so great" thing.  I DO NOT WANT CHILDREN.  I know I will still end up birthing 2 of them; I don't really want them.  After I've got the damn things I may change my mind about those particular ones, but I'm not real fond of the idea.
It's like those little visits are designed to make me feel like shit.  I must be a masochist; I keep going.

Its Monday.  Yippie.  Guess who gets more hours this week?  Fun fun fun.

So we're taking a night off.

Anyone have any thoughts on how we can have a small ceremony without my stepmoster taking it over?  And eloping is more or less not an option.   Yeah...

ha ha, we're going out for a bit.  just me and the fiance and his brother, brian.  lets hope for some fun times, but nothing that will top the butt dance.  because nothing can top the butt dance.


still no real news or anything...my living room is a bit more yellow and i have fresh lavender drying in a bell jar.  life is pretty good, all in all.

I have now fought off most of a wonderful sinus infection that had me down for the count all day yesterday and up half the night hacking my brains out.  I think I'm going to try to sleep sitting up tonight.  Which I hate, with a passion.

So, other than still going "Yay, I'm engaged!" there's not much going on.  I'm on vacation this week, and will be painting my living room.  I think.  I may say f-u-g-i-t and just relax instead.  What do you think?
